Proton VPN interfaces with Network Manager to set up its connections with OpenVPN. So, you need to install 'networkmanager-openvpn' with pacman first. In addition, 'network-manager-applet' is also required on GNOME.

If you are using KDE Plasma, make sure to install 'xdg-desktop-portal-gtk' for it follow your Breeze (or any other) GTK theme and have correct mouse cursor icon and size.

If you are getting unknown errors or are getting asked for secrets, I recommend ensuring that your systems wallet/key service is setup and running. For example, I was running MXLinux with KDE and ProtonVPN gave me these errors. After configuring KDE's wallet service, the application started to work and these errors stop occuring!

Proton VPN: 	v1.12.0 (library: v3.14.0 / api-client: v0.7.1)

So I am able to make protonvpn work on the steamdeck by installing networkmanager-openvpn.
After setting up the sudo password with the command "passwd", the steps that can work are:

sudo steamos-readonly disable

sudo pacman-key --init

sudo pacman-key --populate archlinux

sudo pacman -S networkmanager-openvpn 

sudo steamos-readonly enable

If Valve pushes a large update then you have to install networkmanager-openvpn again.
Works as intended.
Finally to have this running on openSUSE TW, the package in the official repo just does not work, it keeps reporting "unkown API error".

description:
Many of you who haven't arleday MUST install Network Manager, nm-applet and systemd installed and operational to get this VPN tool working. This is reconmened from the Proton VPN team, it's not my reconmendation. But it's needed.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I installed KDE plasma networks and connection manger plus openvpn and plugins and it all seemed to be enough for Proton VPN to work but without installing those things I couldn't get it to work. All of this is in the Discover store so you don't need a command line.
after use vpn, my network crash

I love a good VPN. Proton is the best. They're quick to rollout new features and cross OS support (most of the time).
Only problem I've had when running the Linux client is sometimes it will mess up my networking by blocking DNS and isolating ipv6 indefinitely even after uninstall and restart.

Solution to fix networking errors, remove the block it creates with this command:

sudo nmcli con delete pvpn-ipv6leak-protection

description: I can't figure out why this isn't working. Proton VPN is not connecting here in Nobara. It has worked literally every other distro that I've used. Sooo. Guess I'll be switching back to another distro to get VPN to work.

If you can't connect to the internet without VPN try this:
	Disconnect from VPN and quit the app
	open terminal
	$ nmcli device
	find something with "pvpn", "killswitch" or "protection".
	Then run command:
	$ sudo nmcli connection delete name_of_the_killswitch

After that, never use this VPN again. Issue will be back if you will try to connect to Proton again.

It doesn't matter if you have killswitch off in your app. It connects you to the killswitch anyway. Plenty of people thought they needed to reinstall their system because they broke it. I reinstalled my system 3 TIMES before and every time installed this thing like an idiot. 4th time I knew better.

Great VPN Just like Most product by Proton

For those Having trouble connecting try using Flatseal to give ProtonVPN access to /etc by switching on All system configurations in the filesystem tab
summary: Great Free VPN (How To Fix being unable to Connect)

Update the Flatpak application version of ProtonVPN. Now it refuses to open. Something to do with python depencies not found.

Mal geht das Programm, dann nach automatischen Updates wieder nicht usw. usw. usw.. Unter Windows 10/11 keine Probleme, aber hier unter Linux (Ubuntu 2204) eine absolute Katastrophe.

At times this feels more like a beta version than production. UI is a steep downgrade compared to other platforms and it isn't stable enough to really trust the app not leaking or crashing. If you don't need to rely on it, then it is somewhat usable. Probably still needs half a year of development to catch up. At this point, it might be better to use Wireguard or OpenVPN via your Distros network manager instead of the app.
